title: Rob Alflen
text:
Rob Alflen (born 7 May 1968) is a Dutch <a href="association%20football">football</a> manager and former player who most recently was the manager of Dutch <a href="Eerste%20Divisie">Eerste Divisie</a> side <a href="Helmond%20Sport">Helmond Sport</a>.
Playing career.
Club.
Alflen was born in <a href="Utrecht%20%28city%29">Utrecht</a>. He played for <a href="FC%20Utrecht">FC Utrecht</a>, <a href="Ajax%20Amsterdam">Ajax Amsterdam</a>, <a href="Vitesse%20Arnhem">Vitesse Arnhem</a>, <a href="Sparta%20Rotterdam">Sparta Rotterdam</a>, and <a href="Cambuur%20Leeuwarden">Cambuur Leeuwarden</a> in the <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a>.
Managerial career.
Since 2004, Alflen has been co-presenter of the TV program Namen & Rugnummer on <a href="RTV%20Utrecht">RTV Utrecht</a>. Alflen started his coaching career as a youth coach of FC De Bilt, and later became manager of the first team for the 2006–07 season. In the following season, he became assistant manager of <a href="HFC%20Haarlem">HFC Haarlem</a> but still remained as manager of De Bilt. From 2008 until 2010, he was manager of <a href="FC%20Breukelen">FC Breukelen</a>. In February 2009, he also took a job at <a href="Jong%20FC%20Utrecht">Jong FC Utrecht</a> as manager of the team alongside his manager job at Breukelen.
When <a href="Erwin%20Koeman">Erwin Koeman</a> quit as head coach of FC Utrecht in October 2011, Alflen was assigned as assistant coach of <a href="Jan%20Wouters">Jan Wouters</a> for the first team of FC Utrecht. He became head coach after Wouters left the club in June 2014. On 25 March 2015 <a href="FC%20Utrecht">FC Utrecht</a> said that coach Alflen and his advisor <a href="Co%20Adriaanse">Co Adriaanse</a> would step down from their roles with the Dutch club at the end of the season. On 11 January 2016 he became an assistant at <a href="Heracles%20Almelo">Heracles</a> after <a href="Hendrie%20Kr%C3%BCzen">Hendrie Krüzen</a> left the club. On 16 April 2018, it was announced that Alflen would take over as the head coach of <a href="Helmond%20Sport">Helmond Sport</a> on a two-year contract starting next season. On 8 May 2019, Helmond announced, that they had sacked Alflen after a disappointing season, the worst season in the club's history with only four victories in 38 games.
Personal life.
Alflen's father was the Dutch wrestling champion <a href="Loek%20Alflen">Loek Alflen</a>.
